Data Analysis
Abundance and ant species richness were calculated for the combined transects pairs using all
the information from all sampling methods together. The ant species richness and abundance data
were compared by a nested analysis of variance model, testing the effect of ‘habitats’ (with levels
wetland, cerrado and Eucalyptus) nested in ‘veredas locations’, as random blocks and grouped in a
final factor ‘conservation’ (vereda levels: preserved and disturbed). When necessary, the differences
between treatment mean levels were examined using Tukey’s post-hoc test.
Non-metric multi-dimensional scaling (NMDS) was performed on ant presence/absence data
using the Jaccard similarity measure to produce ordinations of similarity between transects. Wherever
it was possible, ‘hulls’ were constructed on the ordination diagram to delimit outermost boundaries of
each vereda location or habitat. Analyses of similarity (ANOSIM – Two Way) tested for significant
differences in ant composition for the factor ‘habitat’ (with levels wetland, cerrado, eucalypt), and the
factor ‘vereda location’ (with each site as levels). Similarity percentages (SIMPER) identified the
contribution of ant species to the dissimilarity between the selected factors. The above analyses were
performed using Past version 2.04 (Hammer et al., 2001).
Results
Across all areas 7,575 ants were sampled, belonging to seven subfamilies, 32 genera and 125
species. Of this total, 42% of individuals were sampled in the pristine vereda sites, where five genera
and 34 species were exclusive. Besides this, 78.1% of genera and 46% of species were common to
preserved and disturbed ‘veredas locations’. Ant species abundance (from all sampling methods) in
each vereda and habitat is shown in Supplementary Table S1.
We sampled two genera and 34 species exclusively in the disturbed “veredas”. Myrmicinae
and Formicinae were the most speciose subfamilies, with 60 and 30 species, respectively, representing
72% of the total number of species (see Supplementary Table S1). Pheidole (Myrmicinae) and
Camponotus (Formicinae) were the most speciose genera (29 and 24 species, respectively). The most
abundant species in these genera were Pheidole sp.19 (414 individuals) and Camponotus crassus (716
individuals), both of which were present in all “veredas”. However, the high total abundances were
largely influenced by ants with opportunistic behavior, such as Solenopsis invicta (Myrmicinae), with
1,339 individuals and present in all “veredas”. Another pioneer species, with similar opportunistic

Discussion
The present study suggests that the ant assemblage is characterized by habitat type, and the ant
fauna of the cerrado is resilient to surrounding impacts in terms of species richness but not species

composition or relative abundance, thus partially corroborating our hypothesis prediction. The
“veredas” are ecosystems under the influence of seasonal water flooding, and they support a unique
plant community, based on endemic species such as the Buriti, which has a strong engineering role in
the ecosystem. After the Buriti has established in the area, several other tree and shrub species are able
to colonize the flooded margins and stabilize and enrich the soil, creating conditions for further
succession, along with the retention of moisture (Rizzini 1997). The ground and arboreal ant fauna of
these “veredas” is directly linked to the phenomena of flooding, the stratification of vegetation,
geomorphological evolution and colonization by other invertebrates. Therefore, ant species responses
to habitats may be related to how these habitats evolved and how they are preserved.
Eucalyptus monocultures are poor environments in terms of spatial heterogeneity and species
diversity, and they exhibit simplified nutrient cycling and energy dynamics. Such conditions may
contribute to reduced numbers of ant species in these environments (Vallejo et al., 1987) and reduce
the occurrence of specialist species (Pacheco et al., 2009). The ant species that colonize the area after
impact were more aggressive types, and could banish or eliminate the resident species. With all the
impact caused by the preparation for the planting of Eucalyptus, some rare species or specific habitats
may also be eliminated. Accordingly, we found that the diversity of ants in Eucalyptus was lower than
in pristine habitats, but most species found in Eucalyptus were also observed at least somewhere in the
cerrado and wetland. This suggests that the preservation of areas surrounded by the plantations may
favor the colonization of ants in environments with low structural complexity, as is the case with the
Eucalyptus plantation.
Our findings contrast with our predictions that opportunistic and invasive species would
dominate in the Eucalyptus, forming a completely distinct animal community, and therefore highlight
the importance of the legal “Permanent Preservation Areas” attached to each vereda. Besides acting as
a source of species that colonize the agro-ecological habitats, such pristine vereda habitats also
promote the flow of matter and energy between these environments. The “veredas” are true ecological
corridors, functioning as a biological stock, and promoting colonization of disturbed areas where
native vegetation is scarce. On the other hand, the widespread presence of S. invicta in the natural
habitats of veredas reflects the opposite of this exchange phenomenon, representing decreasing quality
of the wetlands and cerrado.
Another interesting indicator of habitat structure dependence was Atta sexdens in the
surrounding cerrado of Vereda P2. Costa et al. (2010) reported that Atta species nests require good,
and well-preserved soil conditions, but are resistant to surrounding impacts, as long as new leaves of
pioneer plants are available. More recent works have shown that Attini species are positive engineers
of forest biodiversity, and are related to high seed dispersal and seedling survivorship (Leal et al.,
2007; Silva et al., 2007; Wirth et al., 2007). Members of the tribe Attini, in particular the genera Atta
and Acromyrmex, have been reported as being abundant in Eucalyptus monocultures (Araújo et al.,

57
1997; Cantarelli, 2005), but this was not observed in this study. Due to high leaf concentrations of
tannins and other deterrent compounds in Eucalyptus, it is an unfavorable habitat for these genera to
nest or forage. Indeed, these genera forage in monoculture habitats only in the initial stages, when the
native vegetation has just been removed for planting (Bento and Della-Lúcia, 1993).
It is worth noting that both wetlands and cerrados contained species requiring high quality of
arboreal habitats, thus reflecting some resilience and resistance of these ecosystems to the impact of
being surrounded by Eucalyptus. The presence of certain genera supports this perception, as
exemplified by species in cerrado such as Mycocepurus goeldii (which nests in soil with rotten logs,
and which takes feces of insects, fruit pulp and seeds to grow its fungal gardens - Pizo and Oliveira,
2000; Araújo et al., 2002), and Ectatomma planidens plus E. brunneum (both aggressive and generalist
predators of other arthropods, or scavengers - Silvestre et al., 2003). Another noteworthy finding in the
cerrado habitat (Vereda P2) was a new, as yet undescribed, species of Xenomyrmex (Forel 1885). The
biology of this genus is little known, but Wheeler and Wheeler (1960) report that this genus builds its
colony in tree cavities and suggest that these ants may not be restricted to the trunks of trees, but rather
descend to the ground in search of food.
Such woody habitat conditions are part of the wetland ecosystems, and apparently could also
be related to the presence of species such Camponotus rufipes and C. melanoticus. Both species are
typical of Brazilian savanna, nesting on the ground or under leaves and are generalist foragers
(Silvestre et al., 2003); they were found in both pristine and impacted “veredas”. In our study, both
species were confined to wetland and cerrado habitats, indicating that the eucalypt habitat do not
provide conditions for nesting and foraging. Likewise, army ants of the species Labidus praedator
were only found in the wetland of Vereda D2, reflecting the availability of considerable amounts of
invertebrate resources to sustain their vagile colonies. On the other hand, “veredas” have both high
availability of food resources and nesting sites, and have proved to be susceptible to establishment by
opportunistic species, such as S. invicta, L. humile and Wasmannia auropunctata. These ants have
polygynous colonies, territorial, aggressive behavior and exhibit generalist foraging on the soil and
trees. This type of niche promotes rapid colonization of the environment, with interconnected nests
leading to a supercolony of cooperative workers, especially after an environmental disturbance. Once
established, colonies displace other species of ants and arthropods, resulting in a general decrease in
species richness and abundance (Delabie, 1988; Diehl-Fleig, 2006).
The presence of S. invicta in cerrado of Vereda P2 may indicate the presence of secondary
impacts in this vereda, such as cattle or other human activities. However, its presence in the cerrado of
Vereda D2 indicates that the disturbances could be caused by nearby Eucalyptus monoculture areas.
The abundance of S. invicta at higher levels than that of W. auropunctata and L. humile in these areas
and in the eucalypt habitat of Vereda D1, suggests that S. invicta is the ant dominating in this habitat.

The present work is the first large ant survey in the vereda ecosystems, and is the first to
provide the background for designing bioindication protocols for diagnosis of the conservation status
of these complex wetland habitats within the Brazilian Cerrado. An example of their use is the impact
on ant species composition and assemblage structure caused by the plantation. For instance, the
number of edaphic ant species in the wetland soils of the “veredas” surrounded by Eucalyptus was
lower than in the preserved areas. Such species composition suggests an accelerated succession
towards a drier ecosystem due to ground water drawdown caused by the monoculture. Based on
geomorphologic data, such succession should be happening faster in some of the preserved areas
instead. Hence, changes in the distribution of ant species among functional guilds appears to reflect
differences in the soil’s capacity for water retention, along with variation in micro-spaces between
grains in the soil and sediment, and vegetation changes caused by human impacts (CB Costa-Milanez,
unpublished data). This supports the hypothesis that ant assemblages are a sensitive community
component, which is a potentially good candidate for bioindication of early impacts caused by land
use change.

Characterization of soil and geomorphology of veredas, with special references to ant fauna and
Eucalyptus monocultures
Abstract
The veredas, Brazilian savanna wetlands, are headwaters with shallow drainages, frequently having
their origin in the contact of two geological rocks of different permeability intercepted by the ground
surface, which results in the surface manifestation of groundwater. In this study we investigated the
response of ant species to landscape, soil and geomorphologic traits of veredas in the northwest part of
the State of Minas Gerais, south-eastern Brazil. We selected four independent veredas, two being
impacted by Eucalyptus monoculture (one younger and one mature) and two with no surrounding
plantations. Ant sampling was conducted in May 2010, February 2011, October 2011 and March 2012
using three complementary methods, namely baits, pitfall traps, and hand collection. A total of 37,956
ants were sampled, belonging to seven subfamilies, 40 genera and 175 species. Ants smaller than 0.5
cm (e.g., Dorymyrmex jheringi and Pheidole gertrudae) predominated in Eucalyptus areas, where on
average, 58% of soil granules belonged to the finest class. On the other hand, the hydraulic
conductivity was higher in the impacted veredas during the wet season, when the organic material
makes the sediment/soil lumpy, maintaining the moisture in the spaces between the grains. The sudden
reduction in groundwater level following the wet season may cause environmental changes which
facilitate opportunistic species to spread throughout, replacing typical habitat-specialized species. Our
study shows that the habitats simplified by human activities may result in loss of diversity and
modification of species composition. Although the mature eucalypts provide habitats for generalist
nesting ant species, it is unlikely to provide conditions for specialist predatory, arboreal and legionary
ants.
Key-words: vereda, savanna, granulometry, Brazil.
Introduction
The main Brazilian savanna (Cerrado) wetlands, so called veredas, are headwaters of shallow
drainages, which mostly have their origins in the contact of two geological rocks of different
permeability intercepted by the ground surface, which promotes the surface manifestation of
groundwater. This ecosystem is formed on sandy soils with high concentrations of peat (Eiten, 1994;
Alencar-Silva and Maillard, 2007), composed of very fine particle size, with large amounts of
decaying organic matter by anaerobic bacteria, resulting in a black colored, wet ground habitat,
colonized by hydrophilic grasses. Therefore, the distribution of soils/sediments is associated with the
Contribuição às Ciências da Terra
73
performance of groundwater which is more near the surface, promoting poor drainage conditions
(Melo 2008). In adjacent areas of these veredas, Cerrado "sensu stricto", soil is characterized as
Latosols composed of quartz sands with high concentration of iron and aluminum, which makes this
acid soil (Gomes 2006).
At an early successional stage, the vereda is exclusively dominated by the Buriti palm tree,
Mauritia flexuosa L. f. (Arecaceae). The Cerrado vegetation surrounding natural veredas represents
infiltration areas, providing recharge surfaces where rain penetrates and feeds the groundwater.
However, during the years 1970 to 2000, 44% of natural Cerrado, including those surrounding
veredas, has been replaced by some sort of plantation. Initially, this ecosystem was cleared for soy and
corn monoculture, but later for stockbreeding, and now for monocultures of Pinus and Eucalyptus
(Viana, 2006).
Eucalyptus is an exotic plant genus from Australia, and its monoculture is usually introduced
into areas with soils of low fertility, such as the Cerrado, or in abandoned pasture, in order to take
advantage of appropriate landscape relief, regardless low fertility, to which this species is well adapted
(Camargo et al., 2004). However, such plantations tend to worsen the local water deficit, soil fertility
and pH, as well as decreasing native fauna biodiversity (Souza et al., 2006; Alcides and Pereira, 2007).
The evaluation of impacts at a landscape scale within an agri-ecosystem requires the
investigation of subtle changes in the ecological community. Such changes may be detected by
monitoring bioindicator species or functional guilds, which are those populations (or assemblages of
species) that promptly, reflect the state of the biotic and abiotic environment. In other words, they are
species or groups that reflect changes in the impacted habitats, communities or ecosystems, or are
representative of overall community diversity (McGeoch, 1998). The ants are considering to be
excellent bioindicators, because they are an extremely abundant group, with relatively high numbers
of species which are taxonomically treatable, with many specialist species occupying different trophic
levels, and react promptly to changes in the environment (Majer, 1983). Ant diversity is influenced by
the diversity and density of plant species physiognomy and stratification, as well as by abiotic factors
such as temperature, humidity, and soil composition (Hood & Tschinkel, 1990; Johnson, 1992). In
addition, ants are important for promoting the formation of channels, pores, and aggregates, which will
influence the transport of gases and ground water, as well as by playing important roles in
geomorphology and soil formation (Coutinho et al., 2003; Lavelle et al., 2006).
In this study, we characterized the geomorphology of veredas, and soil/sediment the habitats
that comprise this veredas: wetland, cerrado and Eucalyptus monoculture. Besides we investigated the
response of ant species to landscape and geomorphologic parameters of veredas under the impact of
Eucalyptus monoculture, located in the northwest part of the State of Minas Gerais, south-eastern
Brazil. There is an urgent need to study the impact of this type of plantation on the vereda in order to

improve and apply conservation measures and laws which aim to protect this unique ecosystem. The
study of soil invertebrates provides the cornerstone of biological monitoring for understanding the soil
dynamics and the more subtle aspects of the changes in soil characteristics (Majer, 1992; Andersen et
al., 2004), such as decline of groundwater and compaction of the upper layers of soil, both of which
are typical disturbances caused by Eucalyptus monoculture.
Materials and Methods
Study Area
The veredas studied in this project are located in the northwest region of Minas Gerais State,
within the cerrado domain. The veredas are located in the municipalities of São Gonçalo do Abaeté
(18°20'16"S and 45°49'58"W), Três Marias (18°15'12"S and 45º15'50"W) and Andrequicé (a district
of Três Marias - 18°27'08.69"S and 044°50'51.12"W (see Fig. 5.1). The plateau range varies from 579
to 1,719 m above sea level composed by eluvial and colluvial cover being at disagreement with their
textural characteristics and facies. In the geological context the veredas occur in two different sets:
Três Marias Formation in the base of Serra do Dilúvio, and Areado Formation on top. The climate in
the high–mid San Francisco river basin is characterized as Aw, according to Köppen's climatic
divisions, being tropical and semi-humid, with an average temperature of 24°C, prevalent rainfall in
summer, and dry winters, and an average annual rainfall of 1500 mm (Ribeiro 2007).

Characterization of the Soil/Sediment and Hydraulic Conductivity
Soil/sediment samples were taken with a borer of 10 cm diameter and 10 cm depth a total 43
samples. To measure proportions of grain sizes, the samples were oven dried for 24 hours at an
average temperature of 40oC, and then weighed. Afterwards, they were passed through an automatic
cleaner with a set of graded sieves, which were mechanically agitated for 30 minutes. After sieving,
the retained soil/sediment in each sieve was distributed into smaller bags, and weighed again. At the
end of this process, the percentage of each fraction (10, 18, 35, 60, 120, 230, 400 Mesh - U.S.Bur.
Soils) was determined. Mineralogical analyses for coarse fraction (granule to fine sand) followed the
methodology proposed by Dias (2004) using a stereoscope, and fine fractions (silt plus clay) were
measured using X-ray diffraction.
Field saturated hydraulic conductivity (Kfs) was measured in both dry (September 2010) and
wet (March 2010) seasons using a Guelph permeameter, as proposed by Dafonte et al. (1999) and Soto
and Vilar (2003). The values of ? used were 0.12 for soils with clay, including fine sand to coarse
fraction, and 0.36 for soils with coarse fraction sand to gravel, including large crevasses and macro
pores.
Ant Sampling
Ant sampling was conducted in May 2010, February and October 2011, and March 2012 using
three methods: sardine/honey baits (soil and arboreal), pitfall traps (soil and arboreal), and hand
collections. Pairs of 20 m transects situated 10 m apart from each other were replicated in three
locations in each habitat (see Fig. 5.2). Pitfall traps and baits were placed 5 m apart along the transect
in an alternating fashion. The hand collecting was performed for one hour in each habitat like Costa et
al., (2010). The ground pitfall traps were adapted from the method used by Holway (2005), but traps
were left in the ground for three days. Arboreal pitfall traps used the methodology proposed by Majer
(1983). The baits followed the method used by Espírito Santo et al. (2012). Sampled ants were sorted
and identified to genus level, and then separated into morphospecies or species by consulting a
specialist. The ants were measured using digital caliper and the soldiers were not counted. The value
0.5 cm was arbitrary. The reference collection is stored at the Federal University of Ouro Preto
(UFOP), Brazil.

Results
Characterization of soil/sediment
The soil and sediments in wetlands and cerrado habitats of the Vereda P1 and P2 is compound
by medium and fine grains, and very course sand and medium grain, respectively. The sediment in
wetland of Vereda D1 and D2 is compound by fine and coarse sand grain, respectively, but cerrado
habitat of Vereda D2 has fine sand grain. The granulometric composition of Eucalyptus habitat in
Vereda D1 and D2 is very fine sand grain. Generally, these grains were mostly compound by quartz,
quartz agglomerates and biotite comprising the sand fraction. However, the higher concentration of
granules and very coarse sand, in Vereda D2, is basically due to agglomeration of the organic matter
and quartz. The mineralogy for the finer fractions was gibbsite, kaolinite, and quartz, as expected for
Brazilian latosolos. However, in Vereda P1 was observed chlorite, and Vereda P2 anatase.
Hydraulic conductivity tests showed low values for the wetland habitat sediments, being close
to or zero at some points (Figure 3). In the cerrado habitats of Veredas P1 and P2, the conductivity
was slightly higher than in the points near to the wetland. In Eucalyptus habitats (Vereda D1 and D2)
there was a large amount of water in the soil, especially in the young monoculture during the dry
season. When wetland habitats have their soils saturated (wet season), they are unlikely to yield lower
values of Kfs than in the dry season (Table 5.1 – Fig. 5.3).

Discussion
The land change by Eucalyptus monocultures leads to a homogenization of the landscape,
promoting loss of local biodiversity (Mentone et al., 2011). With development of eucalypt plantations
near the veredas, this loss of biodiversity can extend to the regional level, since they lead to loss of
connectivity between the fragments. In our study, the impacts of monoculture are not limited to the
loss of spatial heterogeneity, but also to the lowering of groundwater, resulting in the death of plants,
accumulation of dry organic matter, formation of agglutinates which hinder the infiltration of rain
water, and changes in particle size and soil composition due to the use of machinery to cultivate the
soil (Vital, 2007). Therefore, it is necessary to understand how these pedologic transformations of
habitat can affect the resident fauna of the veredas.
The Eucalyptus plantation results in a severe change in the ecosystem, as management of soil
traits results in changes in soil fertilization and structure, which are difficult to reverse. Especially in
poor cerrado soils, the planting begins with soil preparation using tractors, which will dig, cut and turn
over the soil to decompress it, to encourage the establishment of roots of the eucalypts. With the soil
Costa-Milanez, C. B., 2013 Avaliação da Degradação Ambiental das Veredas da Região de Três Marias...
80
tilled, the farmers add phosphorus, potassium and nitrogen to the first 40 cm of soil in order to reduce
losses in the early stages of seedling planting. In this study, we observed that in Eucalyptus
monoculture, there exist a high proportion of fine grains, once the large grains and agglomerates may
have been broken during soil preparation. Some authors, such as Lima (1996) and Martins et al.
(2003) have reported that in monoculture areas there is a loss of fine grains in the early stages by rain
and wind. However, the same was not observed in our work, possibly because the veredas are situated
in a relief of small declivity, and a mild tropical rain regime, with average rainfall of 0.43 mm/month,
which is less likely to wash down the exposed soil.
This whole process promotes changes that may be favorable for some species and not to others.
The highest proportion of fine grains in the soil benefits colonization of species with body sizes
smaller than 0.5 cm. Ants construct their nests and foraging routes by extracting soil particles with the
mandibles, psamóforos , legs and carrying the load taken to another place (Costa et al., 2010). Hence,
ants of approximately 0.5 cm in size are favoured in areas with a higher proportion of fine grains, as
exemplified by the genus Pheidole, particularly Pheidole gertrudae in the Eucalyptus habitat. Of 6,370
individuals sampled during the 4 years of study, 4,413 (69%) belong the genus Pheidole. The small
ants of this genus nest in diverse locations, including soil, litter or trunks, and have large colonies with
massive recruitment (Lizidatti, 2006). All of these characteristics make them effective in colonizing
diverse habitats and excluding competitors.
The other two representative species in the Eucalyptus were Solenopsis invicta and Dorymyrmex
jheringi, both aggressive colonizers, and potentially invaders. These two species inhabit areas with
unbalanced ecological conditions, for example, monoculture areas. However, this did not prevent these
ants from colonizing native habitats. These ants have aggressive behavior and their colonies displace
other species of ants and arthropods out of their territories, resulting in a general decrease in species
richness and severe change in species composition (Helms and Vinson, 2002). Another noteworthy
change in the Eucalyptus habitats (Vereda P2) was a new, as yet undescribed (Feitosa oral
information), specie of Ectatomma. The ants of this genus nest in soil or underground and are
predators of other arthropods. Hence, clearly Eucalyptus habitat has less species richness than cerrado
and wetland habitat, but provides generalists and opportunistic species with a food resource.
In contrast, the wetland habitats had less fine grains due to the accumulation of organic matter.
The organic material makes the sediment/soil lumpy, maintaining the moisture in the spaces between
the grains. Thus, it is expected that in the edges of the wetlands there will be low hydraulic
conductivity in the wet season, once the soil is saturated. However, in our study we observed the
opposite, especially in the wetlands of the disturbed Veredas D1 and D2, where there exists increasing
hydraulic conductivity during the wet season. These granules form agglomerates by the process of
agglutination, or by contraction/relaxation of soil clays. In the dry season, these grains are so
agglutinated that this prevents the passage of water, which could not occur in the rainy season, thus
Contribuição às Ciências da Terra
81
increasing the hydraulic conductivity. In the veredas where there are Eucalyptus monocultures, this
process is accentuated by reducing the groundwater level, forming more agglomerates, and thereby
having some potential negative effect on the number of ant species with body size smaller than 0.5 cm.
Such geomorphologic patterns may have direct influences on the distribution of specialized
organisms. For instance, Lavoisiera bergii cogn. (Melastomataceae) is a plant restricted only to
Vereda D2, where there was a high proportion of agglomerates, a phenomenon quite likely related to
the high absorption of water that follows early establishment of eucalypt monoculture (Souza et al.,
2006). This shrub is described in association with flooded and open areas of veredas (Somavilla and
Graciano-Ribeiro, 2011). Eventually, in the Vereda D2 all individuals of this species were found dead,
suggesting a recent change in the water availability. Similarly, Neivamyrmex pseudops (Forel 1909)
was also found at the exact same areas. This ant has an aggressive behavior and is nomadic, stabilish
its colony in poor fallen logs or in leaf litter, but has the habit of hypogaeic foraging (Silvestre et al.,
2003). The noticeable numeric presence of a hypogaeic species must reflect a dry terrain, otherwise it
could certainly not build its foraging channels.
Among the preserved and disturbed wetlands, there was no difference in the number of species.
However, in preserved wetlands, ants like Solenopsis invicta (Buren 1972) and Wasmannia
auropunctata (Roger 1863) were found in a disproportionately high abundance, which an indicative of
other likely impacts, rather than Eucalyptus. These two ants are native to Brazil and have high ability
to invade disturbed habitats, disrupting the invertebrate fauna, eventually transforming the entire
biological community. Wasmannia auropunctata was found in high abundances in the wetland of
Vereda P1, and S. invicta in wetland of Vereda P2. Although they are common in Neotropical lowland
forests, they usually do not dominate intact communities (Wetterer and Porter, 2003). Likewise, the
presence of Pseudomyrmex termitarius (Smith 1855) in P2 may also reflect the existence of impacting
events, as this species is commonly found in disturbed areas (Delabie et al., 2000). Secondary
evidence corroborates that cattle presence, fire and frequent human presence (for leisure or cattle
management) could be related to occasional but significant disturbances in these ecosystems.
The cerrado habitat had 13 exclusive species, including generalist predators such as Anochetus
(inermis gr.) sp.1, Oxyepoecus vezenyii (Forel 1907), Pachycondyla stigma (Fabricius 1804), and the
litter specialist predator Strumigenys denticulata (Mayr 1887). In the cerrado habitat of Vereda D2,
adjacent to the mature Eucalyptus plantation, opportunist species like Crematogaster acuta (Fabricius
1804), C. torosa (Mayr 1870) and C. nr. obscurata (Emery 1895) dominated the trees. These species
primarily occur in open areas, seasonally dry areas, and highly disturbed habitats, such as pasture
edges or monocultures (AntWeb, 2012). This result suggests that monoculture did not offer nesting
sites (dead branches or logs) or foraging areas (extrafloral nectaries and dead arthropods) for these
species, as their occurrence was restricted to the native habitat, making an irrefutable measure of
Costa-Milanez, C. B., 2013 Avaliação da Degradação Ambiental das Veredas da Região de Três Marias...
82
species diversity decline within the siviculture. Besides the direct habitat simplification in plantation,
after every eight years (for charcoal, bollard, cellulose) and 13 years (for wood), the impact in soil and
vegetation happens again (Higa et al., 2000). By the end of the three successive rotations, the mature
plantation of Eucalyptus causes a physical, chemical and biological degradation in the soils. The
number of microorganisms is reduced, which leads to loss of nitrogen and phosphorus, once the rate of
decomposition decreases (Rezende et al., 2001).
No other savanna vegetation in the world has great plant diversity as the cerrado has (Goodland,
1971; Goodland and Ferri, 1979). Therefore, stronger and more effective conservation measurements
to protect this biome are urgently needed, especially for the veredas, due to their thin and small areas,
as well as their transient ecological state, which makes them very vulnerable due to their low-resilient
communities. The study of ant fauna could provide early warning indication of this degrading process,
inclusive of the transformation of the abiotic conditions caused by monoculture, allowing rapid
diagnosis of the impact of eucalypt monoculture in the cerrado and vereda habitats.

Effect of Fire on Ant Assemblages in Veredas of Brazilian Cerrado
Abstract
The Cerrado is a biome whose evolution and diversity is largely related to the effect of fire. However,
even with many species adapted to the occurrence of fire, it can negatively affect the ecological
community when happening at certain times in the dry season, especially if affecting habitats not fully
adapted to it. Using ants as bioindicators of changes in biodiversity and environmental conditions, this
study evaluated the effects of fire in two Cerrado vegetation types: “cerrado” sensu stricto, a xeric
savanna, and “vereda wetlands”, a mesic vegetation where water concentrates and ultimately flows
towards rivers. We examined the effects of fire on both habitats, but with special consideration to the
wetlands, which are not fully adapted to fire. Ant sampling was conducted twice before and twice after
the fire. We sampled ants using 144 baits (soil and arboreal), 208 pitfall traps (soil and arboreal), and
hand collecting along three random replicate transects per area. The richness and the abundance of ant
species were not affected by fire. Ant species richness and abundance were resilient to fire in cerrado
habitats, also showing a remarkably consistent seasonal variation, again regardless of the fire. On the
other hand, the fire changed significantly the ant species composition in the vereda habitat. In these
wetlands, the fire spread underground because of the high concentration of peat. Due to this and the
fact that the vereda vegetation has little adaptation to root and trunk heating, the impact on ant
assemblages was substantial and visually perceptible. The capability of the wetlands to recover their
original community characteristics and species composition is uncertain.
Key words: mesic environments, bioindication, Formicidae, wetlands.
Introduction
The Brazilian Cerrado is a mosaic of vegetation types, interspersed savanna formations,
woodlands, grasslands, gallery forests and wetland vegetation, whose composition is mainly
determined by edaphic conditions and the effects of fire (Eiten 1972; Vasconcelos et al. 2009). The
fire in Cerrado is an ancient phenomenon, evidenced by the presence of charcoal samples dated
between 27,100 to 41,700 years b.p. (Vicentini 1993), before the arrival of Portuguese discoverers
(Coutinho 1982). Fire is considered as one of the most influential factors defining the Cerrado’s
physiognomic diversity (Sato 2003). The different phytophysiognomies is compound by presence of
shrubs and trees on an herbaceous stratum without forming a continuous canopy, occur under the
influence of well-defined seasons with low average precipitation. The coexistence of these stratums in

the Cerrado is only possible because of the interactions between life histories and disturbance, such as
fire or herbivory (Van-Wilgen 2009).
The intensity and frequency of fire are also important because they will determine the
homogeneity or heterogeneity of the habitat. As more frequent the fire, less intense it is, because there
is no accumulation of litter on the ground. These fires consume more herbaceous substrate and
seedlings, which hardly reach adulthood in burned areas constantly. Fire alters drastically
microclimate and habitat heterogeneity, leading to modification in the community dynamics, with
associated changes in species diversity and composition (Kapos 1989). On the other hand, the total
exclusion of fire in prone ecosystems could reduce the resilience, once the accumulation of fuel caused
by attempts to fire exclusion in these ecosystems weakens the resilience to enable favorable conditions
for fires very intense and also reduce the diversity of herbaceous species (Ramos-Neto & Pivello
2000).
Despite the long term adaptation of Cerrado community to fire like rhytidome thick, tubers,
bulbs, corms and rhizomes underground, it could have a negative impact at an ecological time scale.
For instance, there are records of 97% of plant biomass destruction, local extinction of tree species that
are only recruited by seeds, and severe release of greenhouse gases into the atmosphere (Cortês et al.
2011). The effect of fire can be even more pronounced in ecosystems sensitive to change and with
little capacity for regeneration, such as wetland communities (Alves & Silva 2011). This is the case of
veredas situated in the Cerrado, which are wetland ecosystems formed on sandy soils with high
concentrations of peat, and which are responsible for recharging important aquiferous reservoirs of the
Central Brazilian Plateau. They are ecological and socially important wetland systems (Oliveira &
Ferreira 2007; Ferreira 2009), initially colonized by an endemic species of palm, the Buriti (Mauritia
flexuosa L. f.). The extent of the impacts of fire on the Cerrado biome is known (Coutinho 1978;
Coutinho 1982; Coutinho 1990; Hoffmann 1996; Alves & Silva 2011; Cortês et al. 2011), but to
veredas is poorly understood and there isn’t papers explain the fire impact, especially ant fauna. Exist
an urgent need to improve our knowledge on this impact, as fire rates escalate yearly due to climate
change (i.e. longer dry seasons, smaller time interval between El Niño Phenomena) and the expansion
of agriculture and cattle farming.
We studied the effects of fire in the wetland vereda and Cerrado sensu stricto using ants as tools
to evaluate changes in biodiversity and environment conditions. Ants respond acutely to subtle
changes in soil features, such as soil compaction, consequently water permeability, and spatial
heterogeneity (Majer 1992; Majer & Delabie 1994; Costa et al. 2010; Andersen et al. 2012), and thus
may provide insights about the impact of fire on the ecological functionality of wetland veredas. We
examine how the ant species richness, abundance and composition will respond to the fire impact in
cerrado and wetland habitat. We predict that ant response will be stronger in the wetlands than in the
cerrado, due to its lower resilience to loss of heterogeneity along with lack of plant species adaptation

to fire events. We further predict that with the death of some colonies previously present, generalist

Material and Methods
Study Area
The area of Cerrado studied in this project is located in the northwest region of Minas Gerais
State. The veredas are located in the municipalities of São Gonçalo do Abaeté (18°29'10.61"S and
045°40'03.01"W) and Andrequicé (a district of Três Marias - 18°27'08.69"S and 044°50'51.12"W. The
climate in the region of the high–mid San Francisco river basin is characterized Aw, according to
Köppen's climatic divisions, being tropical and seasonal, with an average temperature of 24°C,
prevalent rainfall in summer and dry winters, and an average rainfall of 1000 mm to 1800 mm
(Ribeiro 2007).
The field work was carried out in two independent locations: a preserved vereda (Curral das
Éguas, Control Site) with an adjacent area of cerrado (sensu stricto); and a vereda disturbed by fire
(São José, Burned Site) with a neighboring cerrado (sensu stricto) area which was also burnt (see Fig.
6.1). Both veredas are geomorphologically classified as hillside (Boaventura 1978), and have
vegetation predominantly composed by Alismataceae, Arecaceae, Asteraceae, Cyperaceae, and
Melastomataceae. The fire occurred during the prolonged and intense dry season of 2011, under the
influence of an El Niño year. The two vereda sites are composed by both wetland and cerrado habitats,
within each we settled three replicated transects (Fig. 6.1). Hereafter, the two habitat zones are referred
to as: We – wetland habitas, under the direct influence of yearly floods, and Ce – cerrado habitats
surrounding the wetland.

Ant Sampling
Ant sampling was conducted in May 2010 and February 2011, before the fire, then October 2011and
March 2012, after the fire (we don’t know the exactly fire day and if was more than one day). Three
replicated 20 m linear grid, with 10 m between replicates, were established in each habitat (see Fig.
6.1). The distance of 10 m between transects them as independent features, as evidenced by Ribeiro et
al. (2013). We used three complementary sampling methods, namely baits (soil and arboreal, a total of
288), pitfall traps (soil and arboreal, a total of 372), and hand collections (a total of 20). Pitfall traps
was placed alternating with baits, 5 m apart from each other along the linear grid. The ground pitfall
traps were adapted from the method used by Holway (2005), but traps were left in the ground for three
days. Arboreal pitfall traps used the methodology proposed by Majer (1983). The baits followed the
method used by Espírito Santo et al. (2012). The hand collection was performed for one hour in each
habitat, as in Costa et al. (2010). Sampled ants were sorted and identified to genus level, and then
separated into morphospecies or species by consulting a specialist. The reference collection is stored at
the Federal University of Ouro Preto (UFOP), Brazil.
Data Analysis
Abundance and ant species richness were calculated for the combined transects pairs using all the
information from all sampling methods together. The ant species richness and abundance data were
compared by a nested analysis of variance model, testing the effect of fire on the richness and

To investigate further the change in species composition, we performed Cochrans Q Test, which

Results
A total of 20,519 ants were collected across all methods, belonging to seven subfamilies, 32
genera and 143 species. The ant assemblages sampled were predominantly composed the subfamilies
Myrmicinae and Formicinae, with 72 (50%) and 30 (21%) species, respectively. Before fire, 10,609
ants were collected, distributed in 113 species. In the cerrado habitat the most abundant species was
Crematogaster nr. obscurata (Emery), and in the wetland habitat Pheidole gertrudae (Forel) was the
most abundant. After fire, 9,910 ants were collected, distributed in 110 species. In both cerrado habitat
Crematogaster torosa (Mayr) and Crematogaster acuta (Fabricius) were the most abundant species,
and in the unburned and burned wetland habitat Atta sexdens (Linnaeus) and Solenopsis invicta
(Buren) were most the abundant species, respectively.
In the burned sites, ant species in the vereda wetlands before the fire was 56 species, while after
the fire the number of species decreased to 38, with only 26 species being common to the before and
after fire samples. After the fire, a drastic reduction in abundances of Camponotus rufipes (Fabricius)
was observed and colonization by species such Solenopsis invicta occurred in wetland habitats. By
contrast, the cerrado had 68 species before the fire, but after the fire this increased to 71 species, with
44 species being common to samples taken before and after the fire. Some opportunist species, such as
Crematogaster acuta, Crematogaster torosa and Forelius maranhaoensis (Cuezzo) appeared after the
fire.
Overall ants species richness did not change appreciable in response to fire, comparing control

Discussion
Fire promotes environmental changes such as availability and quality of biomass, species
diversity and energy flux (Peterson et al. 1998), which many times are early detected by faunal
changes (Fox et al. 1999; Costa et al. 2010; Ribas et al. 2012). For instance, in the first weeks after the
fire in Australia, generalist and opportunistic ant species move into the disturbed areas, thereby
increasing the number of species and individuals in these areas (York 1994). On the other hand, fire
reduces the abundance of other arthropod groups, such as collembolans, mites, and beetles, which are
killed or forced to disperse to unburned sites (Gillon 1983). A similar pattern found by York (1994)
for ants was also observed for ants in veredas burned after October 2011. This effect could be detected
up to 5 months after the fire in our study. However, the lack of change in species richness or
abundance in the present case was due to a compensation of species shifting after the fire, which was
then clearly detected by analyzing the species composition, as the increasing numbers of generalist
species off-setting the loss of resilient species populations.
Despite the invasion of more generalist species and disappearance of more sensitive ones in all
fired sites, the cerrado vegetation kept a higher proportion of its original fauna compared with the
wetlands (65% in the cerrado against 46% for wetlands). As a consequence, the overall summing up of

species in cerrado was positive, with an add of five percent against an overall loss of 38% of species
diversity in the wetlands. The soil of cerrado is comprised of quartz sands with a high concentration of
iron and aluminum (Gomes 2006), which are traits that prevent the fire from spreading underground,
and may be related to the well known resilience of cerrado community to fire. The vegetation has
several adaptations to fire, such as the possession of thick rhytidome, and xylopodium, tubers, bulbs,
corms and underground rhizomes, which assist them to survive the fire (Bond & Keeley 2005; Silva &
Batalha 2010). The species of ants with colonies no deeper than 5 cm in the soil have lower chances of
surviving fire, due to exposure to flames and associated high temperatures (Morais & Benson 1988),
which may range from 85°C to 840°C in the air, and 29°C to 55°C in the ground at 1 cm depth (Frizzo
et al. 2011 a). Nevertheless, ants with deeper nests are more likely of surviving, as natural fires do not
cause large elevations in the underground temperatures (Coutinho 1978). This is the case with the
Attines (Atta and Acromyrmex), which build deep nests, and which due to their architecture are able to
stabilize fluctuations in temperature and humidity (Farji-Brener 2000, Carvalho et al. 2012).
In this fire scenario, C. rufipes suffered a considerable reduction in the number of individuals,
especially in the wetland habitat after the burn. This species nests on the ground forming tall mounds
of litter and fine debris (similar to the temperate Formica rufa) which are then burned intensively.
However, the colony may survive due to arboreal satellite nests, as described by Espírito Santo et al.
(2012). Such strategies may reflect the general adaptation of typical savanna species to survive
common fire events. However, after fire a decline in the colonies may be observed in part be due to
the reduction of food resources used for this ant, or because the fire burned the colony. Similar causes
may be related to the decline of the genus Crematogaster after fire. Crematogaster nr. obuscurta
almost disappeared from the cerrado canopy, which was then colonized by C. acuta and C. torosa. The
genus Crematogaster is a cosmopolitan lineage of Myrmecinae, and majority of species nest in trees
(Hölldobler & Wilson 1990). Crematogaster torosa and C. acuta occur primarily in open and
seasonally dry areas, which are often highly disturbed, and nest in dead wood (AntWeb 2012). These
features may favor their colonization after fire. In contrast, C. melanoticus, another species typical of
the Brazilian savanna, did not change in abundance after the fire. The fire can interfere with the
survival rate of certain species, destroying their basic niche requirements, but can give advantage to
other species better adapted to live in more xeric conditions (Frizzo et al. 2011 b).
The fire has a strong potential to damage wetlands, where the plant species tend to have no
mechanisms for fire protection (Maillard et al. 2009). Furthermore, the wetland’s soil is rich in peat,
which can lead to underground fires, with high temperatures causing severe damage to plant roots,
which can further increase the rate of local extinction of many species. The impact of fire was more
substantial in the wetland habitat resulting in a more intense post-fire colonization by generalist ant
species such as Pheidole gertrudae, Dorymyrmex jheringi and Solenopsis invicta. These genera live in
various habitats, ranging from the humid tropics to deserts (Naves 1985; Helms & Vison 2002),
especially in the litter and soil, have populous colonies, and are aggressive, competitive and

omnivorous. The combination of these characteristics makes them effective at colonizing many
habitats and excluding competitors (McGlynn 1999; Ramos et al. 2003). Nonetheless, we cannot say
the same for the genus Ectatomma. After fire in the wetlands, one of the seven species of this genus in
this study disappeared, with E. brunneum (Smith) being the only species to be sampled again in
wetland burned areas. This species lives in secondary forest, is a generalist predator of terrestrial

contrast, in the resilient cerrado habitat four species of this genus survived the fire. It’s worth noticing
that E. edentatum was hardly affected by the fire. Being an aggressive, generalist predator or
scavenger, foraging in vegetation or on ground (Silvestre et al. 2003), this species managed to
maintain its abundance after the fire event.
Our results suggest that the wetlands are less resilient than the surrounding cerrado to the impact
of fire. The lack of plants adapted to fire in this vegetation, along with the soil traits that favor intense
burn in the ground, may have reduced soil meso - and macro-fauna. Fire promotes the formation of a
surface crust, which reduces the porosity and water infiltration into the soil, leading to drying out of
the wetland veredas, with immediate consequences to the soil fauna (Spera et al. 2005). There is a
growing concern in relation to the ecological and evolutionary consequences of these stresses on
natural populations (Moretti et al. 2006). Although some species benefit from the fire, some unique,
sensitive, species may disappear without substitutes for their vacant niches. Further, ecological
functions may be seriously affected by increasing populations of dominant, generalist species
(Andersen et al. 2012).
There are still conflicts concerning the utilization of veredas, which is becoming a challenge for
biodiversity conservation in the Brazilian savanna. The practice of burning the wetland veredas is
particularly common in some Brazilian states, such as Tocantins, Maranhão and Piauí, but research on
the effects of fire on fauna and flora of the veredas is still lacking. One should concern about
irreversible consequences for biodiversity and ecosystem functionality, as the wetland veredas are
essential for maintaining the hydrological system, since they act as natural sponges for watercourses
(Meirelles et al. 2006), playing an essential role in the protection of springs that feed the rivers.

DISCUSSÃO
7.1) PERDA DA HETEROGENEIDADE ESPACIAL
Em nosso trabalho verificamos que não existem diferenças entre a riqueza e abundância de
espécies de formigas entre as veredas (planície de inundação + cerrado; ou planície de inundação +
Eucalypto; ou planície de inundação + cerrado + Eucalyptus). Entretanto, quando analisamos a riqueza
e abundância dos habitats separadamente verificamos que existe uma variação na riqueza e abundância
de espécies de formigas. As planícies de inundação por estarem sob influência direta do fluxo de água
possui uma fauna de formigas mais específica, adaptada a essa variação do nível de água e da
disponibilidade de recursos. Já as formigas do habitat de cerrado não precisam lidar com essa variação
do nível de água, mas participam de uma assembleia mais rica e abundante, que pode promover uma
maior disputa por território e por recurso alimentar. Toda essa complexidade do habitat (diversidade
de micro-habitats e interações intra e intere específicas) e promove uma composição de espécies de
formigas também diferenciada entre os três habitats, devido ao aumento dos diversos sítios de
nidificação, qualidade e quantidade de recurso disponível, microclima e solo.
Por outro lado, nos habitats de monocultura observamos o mesmo resultado observado por
Calviño-Cancela et al. (2012). Eles observaram que a diversidade de espécies vegetais vai decaindo
com o passar dos anos dentro das monoculturas. No início do plantio você encontra uma diversidade
maior de plantas, devido a sementes ou brotos deixados para trás no momento do preparo do solo, mas
com o passar dos anos há perda dessa diversidade por causa das substâncias alelopáticas, pouca
retenção de umidade, baixa concentração de matéria orgânica e nutriente do solo, como consequência
a perda estrutural dos microambientes e da heterogeneidade ambiental. Essa simplificação do
ambiente leva a diminuição da riqueza (Costa et al. 2010) e de espécies especialistas, uma vez que a
maioria dos táxons de formigas ocupa nichos mais específicos (Mentone et al. 2011). Sendo assim, a
perda da heterogeneidade pela monocultura de eucalipto, além de promover uma redução na riqueza e
abundância de espécies de formigas, também favorece a colonização de espécies de formigas
pertencentes à guildas mais generalistas, como predadoras generalistas e onívoras de grandes
territórios.

7.2) ASSOCIAÇÕES ENTRE MIRMECOFAUNA E AS CARACTERÍSTICAS DE
SOLO
7.2.1 – Granulometria e Mineralogia
Os solos/sedimentos amostrados nas planícies de inundação e cerrados estudados, são
compostos em sua maioria por grãos com tamanhos entre 2? a 4? (areia média e areia fina), por
mineral quartzo, biotita, e aglomerados. Esse resultado era esperado, pois as rochas que compõem as
áreas estudadas são da Formação Três Marias, mineralogicamente composta por quartzo, feldspato,
muscovita, biotita, clorita (Bacellar 1989, Chiavegatto 1992, Iglesias & Uhlein 2009), e rochas do
Grupo Areado. Uma exceção é uma das planícies de inundação da Vereda D2, onde os grãos possuem
em sua maioria tamanhos entre 0? a 1? (grânulos), compostos por aglomerados de matéria orgânica. O
solo da monocultura de eucalipto apresentou uma maior porcentagem de grãos finos, devido ao
processo de preparo do solo para receber o plantio, compostos pelos mesmos minerais. A fauna de
formigas respondeu a essa variação do tamanho dos grãos do solo/sedimento, uma vez que a
construção dos seus ninhos e canais de forrageamento é realizada através da extração de partículas do
solo com suas mandíbulas, psamóforos e pernas carregando a carga retirada do solo para outro lugar.
O solo/sedimento é coberto por folhas, gravetos e outros obstáculos que podem estar presentes
formando assim um complexo ambiente bidimensional (Yanoviak & Kaspari 2000). Por outro lado,
formigas com tamanho corporal maior conseguem atravessar obstáculos com maior facilidade que
formigas com tamanho corporal menor que fazem sua travessia pelo interstício da serrapilheira como
os gêneros Anochetus, Myrmicocrypta e Stumigenys, mas somente Neivamyrmex possui hábitos
hipógeos. Sendo assim, grandes formigas geralmente forrageiam em cima da serrapilheira, enquanto
que pequenas formigas forrageiam nos canais construídos dentro do solo e por baixo da serrapilheira
encontrada em certos habitats. A complexidade física (estrutural) do solo também é um mecanismo
utilizado pelas formigas que reduzem as interações e competições interespecíficas (Costa et al. 2010).
Por outro lado, os minerais definitivamente parecem não influenciar na mirmecofauna, mesmo
em quantidades elevadas nos grãos de argila, como clorita e anatásio. O mineral clorita
((Mg,Al,Fe)12(Si,Al)8O20(OH)16) foi encontrado na planície de inundação da Vereda P1, que advêm de
uma rocha metamórfica, composta predominantemente de minerais micáceos, como a ardósia. E na
planície de inundação da Vereda P2 foi encontrado o mineral anatásio, que é um óxido de titânio
(TiO2). Este mineral é fonte do elemento titânio, geralmente está associado a rochas alcalinas ou como
mineral secundário, além de possuir baixa solubilidade e alta estabilidade (Dicionário livre de
geociências 2013). Como observado por Lourenço-Silva (2013), somente os metais que são
bioacumulados por plantas que podem influenciar na riqueza de formigas. Algumas formigas
necessitam de maior resistência e rigidez nas mandíbulas e cápsula cefálica, sendo assim elas são
capazes de bioacumular e alocar alumínio e outros metais em suas estruturas corporais (Silva et al.
Contribuição às Ciências da Terra
105
2006; Silva et al. 2009). As formigas conseguem esses metais através dos exudatos das plantas e
honeydew de homópteros que se alimentam dessas plantas bioacumuladoras. Mas, os minerais livres
no solo/sedimento não interferem na colonização de formigas epigeias.
7.2.2 – Permeabilidade
Na vereda que abriga a monocultura de Eucalyptus mais antiga (eucalipto próximo do ponto
de corte), tivemos a oportunidade de observar pontos sem água, o que levou a formação de
aglomerados de matéria orgânica no sedimento da planície de inundação. Em seu estágio inicial, o
Eucalyptus, absorve uma grande quantidade de água necessária para o rápido crescimento, o que pode
ter promovido o déficit hídrico local. Um dos fatores que nos leva a pensar sobre esse déficit hídrico, é
a morte de uma população de Lavoisiera fragilis, uma melastomatácea típica de ambientes alagados,
que atualmente se encontra seca na planície de inundação da Vereda D2. E o aparecimento do gênero
Neivamyrmex, uma formiga de correição que possui hábitos epígeos tanto quanto hipógeos. Como
exposto por Davidson (1993) e Foelkel (2005), as monoculturas plantadas próximas à bacia
hidrográfica facilitam o consumo de água pelo eucalipto, que irá crescer rapidamente, promovendo
impactos sobre os lençóis freáticos tanto localmente como à jusante. Como as raízes dos eucaliptos
não ultrapassam 2,5 metros, essa variação também irá depender do nível do lençol freático, tipo de
solo e do clima da região. Em média uma plantação de eucalipto pode consumir através da
evapotranspiração o equivalente entre 800 a 1.200 mm/ano de precipitações pluviométricas. O que não
é um problema para áreas onde a precipitação pluviométrica é elevada, mas em regiões aonde o índice
pluviométrico não chega a 400 mm/ano de chuva, o eucalipto começar a virar um problema sério.
Como em nossas áreas, onde o índice pluviométrico não tem chegado 100 mm/ano de chuva.
Devido às mudanças climáticas, a região oeste australiana está passando por mudanças na
hidrologia devido a falta de chuva, levando pesquisadores a ficar apreensivos com a perda da
biodiversidade nas Florestas de Jarrah. Essas florestas são nada mais que eucaliptos, e o medo da
desertificação promovido pela escassez de água, impulsionou alguns pesquisadores a implementar o
programa “Wungong Catchment Trial”. Este programa retira árvores de Eucalyptus (Jarrah Forest)
para promover o retorno de água em áreas que estão em estágios iniciais de desertificação. Devemos
nos informar mais a respeito dos diversos impactos da monocultura de eucalipto sobre os
ecossistemas, e cobrar de nossos representantes leis mais eficientes de proteção, principalmente para
áreas próximas de nascentes de rios e áreas de preservação permanente.
7.3) A IMPORTÂNCIA DO FOGO
Como vimos anteriormente o fogo é um evento pontual, secular e ocasional no bioma Cerrado.
Costa-Milanez, C. B., 2013 Avaliação da Degradação Ambiental das Veredas da Região de Três Marias...
106
Mas, podemos dizer que ele é vilão para a fauna de formigas e para todas as fitofisionomias do bioma
Cerrado? Os seus impactos diretos sem dúvida nenhuma afetam não somente a fauna de formigas,
como todo o ecossistema por onde ele passa. Por outro lado, o fogo, ao mesmo tempo em que queima
a vegetação e os animais, pode promover a florescência de plantas, quebrar a dormência de sementes,
originar novos micro-habitats e eventualmente, aumentar a diversidade biológica (Andersen et al.
2012).
Como o efeito do fogo nas assembleias de formigas está relacionado principalmente com seus
efeitos sobre a estrutura da vegetação e o solo, o fogo não é tão avassalador no cerrado, mas sim nas
veredas. No cerrado a vegetação possui adaptações contra o fogo, o solo por não ser alagado e não
possuir elevada concentração de matéria orgânica facilita a construção das colônias subterrâneas pelas
formigas. Portanto, podemos dizer que o fogo tem um impacto limitado sobre a vegetação,
especialmente sobre as assembleias de formigas. Em áreas de baixa precipitação pluviométrica, onde a
estrutura da vegetação possui adaptações a longos períodos de escassez, como nos Cerrados
brasileiros, a vegetação é mais resistente ao fogo. E as formigas que constroem suas colônias dentro
destas árvores, também são beneficiadas por estas adaptações. Em habitats maduros, como os de
cerrado, as perturbações de níveis intermediários não são suficientes para eliminar todos os indivíduos
clímax, o que permite que algumas espécies pobremente competitivas sobrevivam em nichos recém-
abertos nestas áreas recém-perturbadas. Neste cenário, o fogo estaria atuando sobre algumas
populações, reduzindo a competição intraespecífica, o que possibilitaria a manutenção de um número
maior de espécies (Connel 1978).
Por outro lado, as vegetações das veredas não possuem estas adaptações, o sedimento da
planície de inundação é rico em turfas que são altamente inflamáveis, e como o solo permanece
praticamente todo o ano alagado, as formigas não constroem suas colônias em perfis mais profundos.
O fogo queima quase que integralmente a vegetação, além de promover incêndio subterrâneo, devido à
elevada concentração de material combustível (turfa), levando a uma maior mortalidade na assembleia
de formigas. Se o sedimento fica alagado quase todo o ano, como é possível produzir incêndio
subterrâneo? Os incêndios geralmente ocorrem em épocas de seca, e o nível da água tende a descer
nestes meses. Mas, o que agravou o incêndio na vereda estudada foi à monocultura de eucalipto na
área adjacente. Devido ao déficit hídrico promovido pela monocultura, existem alguns pontos nesta
vereda sem água, onde o sedimento começa a ficar mais grumoso. Sendo assim, podemos observar
claramente o efeito do fogo sobre a mirmecofauna, onde há uma redução na riqueza e abundância de
espécies de formigas e uma nova composição de espécies de formigas é formada nas áreas de planície
de inundação a partir de formigas advindas das áreas de cerrado.

CAPÍTULO 8
CONCLUSÃO
Os resultados dessa tese mostraram que as alterações na estrutura do habitat quanto na
estrutura da vegetação promovida pela monocultura de eucalipto reduz à diversidade de espécies de
formigas, e possivelmente de outros invertebrados. A modificação da granulometria do solo/sedimento
é fator determinante do padrão de distribuição e composição da assembleia de formigas de solo, e
pode ser utilizada como uma ferramenta extra para auxiliar no processo de bioindicação em áreas
degradadas pela monocultura. Características do solo/sedimento como mineralogia e a permeabilidade
não demonstraram serem boas ferramentas auxiliares de bioindicação. Também se verificou que as
transformações na estrutura do habitat (vegetação e solo/sedimento) advindas do efeito do fogo
favorecem as formigas generalistas em as áreas de cerrado “stricto sensu”, fitofisionomia que se
recupera rapidamente no pós-fogo. Enquanto nas veredas, o fogo subterrâneo devido ao material
turfoso e a vegetação sem adaptações contra o fogo, resulta em uma mudança na composição de
espécies de formigas.
Ao final deste estudo pode-se concluir que as formigas respondem positivamente em função
da vegetação e da granulometria do solo, que por sua vez abrigam diversos sítios de nidificação,
recursos alimentares como nectários extraflorais, atraem outros invertebrados que irão servir alimentos
para formigas predadoras, e as próprias formigas servirão de recurso alimentar para pequenos
mamíferos, répteis e aves. Com a modificação na estrutura do habitat toda esta rede é quebrada, o que
leva a falência do ecossistema, e não proporciona somente a perda da biodiversidade, mas sim a perda
de várias funções ecossistêmicas que cada membro desta rede realiza. Tornando o impacto muito mais
intenso, principalmente nas veredas que são corredores ecológicos naturais.

APÊNDICE 3
Na planície de inundação da Vereda P1 o sedimento é composto por grãos mais grossos (areia
grossa) e medianos (areia média), tendo em sua composição grãos de quartzo (62%), aglomerados de
quartzo (23%) e aglomerados (13%) em todas as frações. No habitat de cerrado o solo tem textura
mais mediana para fina (areia média e areia fina), mineralogicamente composta por quartzo (68%),
aglomerados (29%) e biotita (3%), como mostra a figura Ap.1. A fração silte/argila na planície de
inundação e no cerrado é composta por gibsita, quartzo e kaolinita, mas também foi encontrado em
dois pontos da planície de inundação clorita e hematita (ver Anexo 1).
Na Vereda P2, o sedimento na planície de inundação da lagoa pode ser caracterizado
granulométricamente, por grãos medianos (areia média), sendo composto em sua maioria por grãos de
quartzo (69%), aglomerados de quartzo (21%), aglomerados (8%), e biotita que perfaz somente 2%
das frações mais finas. O solo do cerrado possui uma textura mediana, sendo composto em sua maioria
por grãos finos (39,63%) e médios (34,04%), mineralogicamente está caracterizado por grãos de
quartzo (59%), seguido de aglomerados (29%), aglomerados de quartzo (7%) e biotita (4%) (figura
Ap.2). Na fração silte/argila os minerais mais representativos para os dois habitats foram gibsita,
kaolinita e quartzo, porém em um ponto na planície de inundação foi encontrado anatásio (Ver Anexo
1), e no cerrado goethita (Ver Anexo 1).
